comments.commentBody:
Paying $60 000 a year to major in English is not the envy of the world.

A nation that can land a man on the moon can operate an exemplary educational system if it wants to. If it does not, the blame rests squarely with the voting public.

AACNY:
"Challenging his critics is not the same as challenging him." I suppose not but...so? At the moment I'm challenging both you and Mr. Douthat. If either of you have better ideas as to how to resolve conflicts between nations and peoples that would sooner destroy one another than sign peace treaties let's hear them. And if your advice is limited to the manner in which he deploys the English language (as opposed to his predecessor's "You're either with us or against us" nonsense) I'd surmise that you don't really see much to complain about.
It is simple. Obama should have invaded, and cut taxes. From the Douthat's crowd, you automatically get an A+ grade for that.

fschoem44 Somers NY:

First mistake is believing the opposition *within* the US should receive the same scrutiny as the president in a foreign policy discussion. Whenever the president stumbles, democrats pivot to focus on the GOP. This is not a GOP problem. It is an Obama Administration problem. The president formulates and directs foreign policy. What's his? That's really the only question that matters.

Foreign policy requires dealing with nefarious players. It's important to size them up accurately . Putin has always been an adversary and, yes, quite dangerous to somebody. I found the reset button to be a combination of foolishness and hubris. Being the new "un-Bush" was a political message that played well domestically. What benefit accrued to the US in the Putin-Obama dynamic from it? It was a waste of a gesture, a throw-away. What were they thinking?

Speaking of wasteful gestures. What was the purpose of Secretary Kerry running off like a crusader in a red cape to solve the Palestinian-Israeli problem without having done any legwork? It was more like Kerry's pet project, his need for a legacy, than a sound diplomatic strategy. Did anyone actually believe he would succeed? Embarking on negotiations that are destined to fail is what novices do.

Foreign policy is about arm-twisting, forming temporary/expedient coalitions and a lot of back channel dealings. The president is simply bad at these. But that's his job whether he likes it or not.

The president's supporters cannot figure out what he might have done differently in many of these conflicts. Unfortunately, the same seems to be true of the president. And therein lies the problem. He appears to have no more idea what to do than they.

People mistakenly believe it is the absence of going to war that is the basis for criticism of the president. Rather, it's the absence of a clearly articulated overall foreign policy strategy. When pressed for details we get baseball metaphors, which doesn't cut it.

At this point, no one wants to hear what the president thinks *about* foreign policy. His opinion *of* foreign policy is irrelevant. We want to hear what US foreign policy actually is.

It is likely that early and pre-humans hunted in groups, making it much easier to capture even very fast animals. Animals could also have been driven to closed canyons or over cliffs. Developing humans might also have eaten animals killed by other animals. This is very common. Top predators must protect their kills from other predators and scavengers. Certainly after humans domesticated dogs they would have used them to run down game.

And this immense lost amount of disposable income is often left out of the economic equation. Odd that my credit card still expects 11% interest while the bank it's associated with wants to pay less than a tenth of that for time deposits.

I wish someone would write about one of the most disturbing lasting effects of the Obama-Bernanke-Geithner bailout of the very banks that set the financial crisis in motion: the extremely low interest rates now paid on savings accounts and CDs. My bank down the street pays a whopping 0.25% on savings accounts and 0.75% on a 5-year CD. ING was paying 5% on my savings account in 2006; Capital One (successor to ING) now pays 0.75%. Ordinary citizens -- and especially senior citizens, who tend to invest in safe instruments like savings accounts and CDs -- have lost an enormous amount of wealth because of such low interest rates, and there is no end in sight. I sarcastically call my savings account my "electronic mattress".
In other words, the U.S. should never have bailed out the banks, who were responsible for pedalling and approving fraudulent mortgages and home equity loans.

Another poster big on sanctimony and assumptions, as well as wrong on the facts. Homeowners mostly did not know they were given loans they could not afford, and many homeowners who were on solid financial ground lost their jobs as well as the value of their homes, and eventually their homes, as the crisis cascaded down the distribution from the least vulnerable and most naive to those less vulnerable and naive. Aim your sanctimony at the banks, finance industry, lawmakers, and voters such as yourself who allow this to perpetuate partly because of being willfully misinformed.
The banks were duped and totally blameless, huh?

The bedrock of American prosperity is Responsibility -- you are responsible for what you do!  How can buyers of these homes which were in reality beyond their capability, or people who knowingly engaged in spending more than that they could actually afford be now offered a way out from public funds?  The American Middle Class, the foundation of America, remains the most productive and constructive because its members takes responsibility for their respective individual actions.  No matter what one states, America should not bail out another group of people who should have known better.  He who followed Greed, should pay for it too!
Sure thing. Let's just add $5 trillion dollars to the Federal Debt. What could possibly go wrong?

Not the same - businesses operate on short term loans and paybacks and a responsive banking system, so the system but not individual bankers/financiers needed to be rescued, but the mortgage crisis should have been dealt with quickly as well. Also needed a large haircut for individuals in the finance/banking industry, taking back of bonuses AND salary, and jail time - some say the laws need to catch up, but a lot of what was done and not done was by choice.

Said it before, years ago, saying it yet again: What should have been done, that would have worked: the Government should have given $50,000 to each household in the US.

For those having a difficult time with the concept, it would have been only a token to someone wealthy, yet would have meant everything in the world to those far down the ladder. The collateral benefit would have been the same saving of the banking system as the bailouts.

Jonathan, you assume that their cash flow is entirely from debt. Cleaning the excess debt off their personal balance sheets would have freed up cash flow for purchases, instead of debt service.

Will creditors wise up? Gee, of course all those banks and rating agencies will wise up and stop peddling financial garbage, wont they? Nope, not as long as their horizon ends at their next annual bonus or quarterly earnings numbers.

The actual reason folks borrowed so much was because they were allowed to by the lenders. The lenders allowed this since they in turn were allowed to pass on these loans to investors in the form of MBS and ultimately CDO's.
The CDO's were bought by investors looking for extra yield and soothed by the AAA rating given by the credit rating agencies. Everything was greased by giant commissions earned on every step of the process.
Market discipline was nowhere in sight until the foreclosures started. Once that happened the horse was out of the barn. Suggesting that loan forgiveness would have avoided the consequences of this great recession is to ignore the reality of the market, as inefficient as it actually is.
Re Jonathan: creditors who face no liability have nothing to wise up to; that was the whole problem with the sub-prime crisis.

The description of the process of economic collapse is exactly on point.  What is missing is why homeowners borrowed against home equity to make purchases.  That is because real wages have been flat for 30 years.  Increasing consumer debt is now the only source of growth in consumer spending.  Even Henry Ford realized workers had to receive a living wage in order to buy cars.  If we want a healthy economy, the pie must be shared.

The significance of Ai Weiwei’s work is much larger than its power of protest, or its ranking as art.

The deeper value is how it can serve any of us to become ever more aware of what it means to meet the criteria of effective communication, no matter what we are responding to. I’m speaking of communication that is respectful of the heart and mind of all who encounter it, communication that is arresting, emotionally powerful, meaningful and memorable––and therefore can serve the human family basically forever.

That almost all communication we encounter, or create, falls short of this ideal suggests just how difficult it is to embrace and express the depthless beauty that resides in every situation, regardless of how mundane, or painful.
Lets say, pretty slow and borning movie!
Actually that's a myth. Both versions end with Kong victorious.

The trailer, or at least the film it implied, was far better than the movie which I could barely sit through. This rendition is, well, goofy and poorly conceived, too. Made me feel sorry for the CGI artists who aren't the ones to blame.

Actually, most of the tripe coming out of Hollywood is designed for viewers to "just relax and be entertained."  What would be a change is to have a movie with a bankable star like Mr. Hamm challenge and provoke.  It is for this reason that I applaud Matthew McConaughey's recent vehicles.

We saw it and liked it. It's not Oscar material but not every movie has to be. Sometimes it's good to just relax and be entertained.

It's a nice change to see a movie where people are treating each other well, enjoying themselves and doing something positive, especially when the movie is based on a true story.

comments.commentTitle: Paul G is a movie genius
comments.commentBody: Freaking hilarious in a freaking hilarious subtle way. Very cool. Watched it several times and it keeps getting better. Love this movie.

comments.commentTitle: Competent film critic does a fine job
comments.commentBody:
Thank you for this objective, well-written and accurate review. I enjoyed it much more than the film!

Keep up the good work; I'll be back for more.

Stephen Beard,

it is dangerous to generalize about generations. In my experience, while there are some very prominent baby boomers who are obsessed with low taxes, it is the aging Great Generation types, indoctrinated by their peer Ronald Reagan, who have been the leaders in the "no new taxes" movement. After all, think of Prop 13 in California, it was a 70's phenomenon. Daddy Bush, the Koch brothers--the various conservative think tankers are funded by geezers. The Great Generation is dying out, but their "we pulled ourselves up by our bootstraps" mentality is the origin of the current problem.

I believe the phrasing of the survey question does not give an option for a possible correct answer.  What about "Regularly or Frequently" as a choice between "Weekly or More" and "Occasionally"?  I suspect many steady churchgoers who attend several times a month but not necessarily every single Sunday.

I'll tell you why the economy's health, rightfully, takes a backseat to the social and environmental problems we have. It's very simple: the economy is one of many aspects of society, not the other way around. That's why.

Wow..it seems like Harry Reid campaign to find a "bogeyman" in the conservative party is catching on at the NYT. I guess Harry can see that the present administration has little to be proud of so a good offensive is better than a defense when you have accomplished nothing and the President seems to be "politically on" 24/7.

It would be nice to see Washington more concerned about rebounding the economy instead of just pandering to special interest. I cannot understand how the economy's health does not take precedence over all the social and environmental agendas that this administration has.

It is very sad..because if the economy was robust today we could be paying down our debt (wait till the interest rates go up) and paying for all these social agenda items that the present administration hopes will distract the electorate this fall.
Seems to me today's libertarian party has been again hoodwinked.  The Koch boys sure sound like a couple oligarch wannabes in 1980.  But then maybe it's finally worked for them.
And here I thought she was writing about Rice.
They also don't intend on being confronted by ideas that conflict with their own--the very definition of narrow-mindedness, &, I would add, cowardice.
Yes.  Politeness in the face of evil & corruption is overrated.
Now, let's hope they vote!

We're seeing the younger generation in action that's been watching their parents and those "in-charge" and are disgusted with the glib, delusional rationalizations for self-serving, amoral behavior gulped down by much of the baby boom generation.

This younger generation has borne the brunt of the pervasive, wide-spread destructive results of those delusions.

However, they don't reject it by growing long hair, creating chaotic music, numbing-out on drugs, worshiping a B-movie cowboy, and groveling before religious charlatans claiming to know God's plan. They don't reject it by wearing their hats backwards.

They do what they've done ever since media tools connected their lives. Talking among themselves, they identify problems, alert everyone else, who, sharing their generation's values, join in, research facts together, prioritize, and organize a plan of action. They then, as an organized group, personally confront the offending person or people.

In this case, that plan of action led students to reject a war-criminal graduation speaker. It included chasing off a university president whose vision didn't include preparing his campus police to react without aggravating confrontation. They rejected two others they believed caused harm when they had the power to do good.

In this younger generation's world, (also my children's world), hate, bigotry, greed, and murderous harm are not, at any level, motivational tools or the basis for governance. They don't intend on waiting.

It seems absolutely appropriate to expect professors to evaluate their material and consider the layers of meaning contained within that material. It seems like a basic, basic part of the job.

In the course of evaluating the material, the professor should be aware of problematic areas of the text.

(Certainly, professors may need to learn more about just what can be problematic and why. But that's true for everyone, and professors should be expected to engage in lifelong self-education.)

There should be NO accommodation whatsoever.  If a student is so sensitive she should drop the class. Hopefully the student is not an English LIT major.  If so we are becoming a country of idiots.  Accommodation is a euphemism for censorship.  We now live in an oligarchy do we need more censorship?

I think it's perfectly reasonable for a student who knows that they have PTSD to ask the professor if any of the readings will contain references to whatever triggers their anxiety. It's a simple question, easily answered. This would allow the student to prepare ahead of time or to drop the course if necessary.
Asking a professor to warn all students of any and all possible triggers is an impossible task however. Besides, it would give away the plot to the book or film under discussion.

These days colleges have health systems that take mental health seriously. It doesn't seem appropriate for professors to spend time evaluating their materials and second guessing what might be offensive, or triggering, to each student.

Students can approach a faculty member with specific concerns and expect a reasonable accommodation in unusual circumstances.

I smiled ruefully and shook my head sadly in agreement when I read your closing 'graf. Back in the 1980s, I was on the staff of the New York Stock Exchange, working in the Product Development Div. The senior vice president of the department came back from some meeting with a bunch of eager-eyed "kids" who had freshly-minted graduate degrees in business from the Ivy League, Stanford, Chicago, etc.

He stepped into my office and when I asked him how the meeting went, Chris sighed, "The rise of the MBA is going to lead to the downfall of America. I just spent two hours with highly educated idiots, know-it-all's who have no idea how little they actually know."

I could not get hired today, having been terminated several times, the HR software would disqualify me immediately.

A few times I just did contracting until something better showed up. I could get away with it because I could do electrical contracting and always pick up enough work to stay solvent. But when certain jobs opened up, I had the skills they needed, so got my share of jobs.

The HR software can not evaluated skills or special abilities, so they get the LCD. The problem with being unemployed for long periods is the work to be done has changed enough that even a few months and you are behind the latest advances, and some newcomer is there to take you place at a lower wage. Employers no longer care about employee loyalty. Now you are a throw away employee.

This is the MBA century, where the only thing that counts is how much costs can be cut. Fortunately, I had a cure for that. Just cut my income and see how long the light stay on. Then they hire some yoyo light bulb changer to get an NC machine back on line, and it costs them twice as much to have a skilled tech repair the damage.

But that is how the MBA mind works. The have no concept of how things work, just costs and profits.

KO2CH = Potassium Formate. May cause irritation of respiratory tract. May cause allergic skin reaction. Avoid contact with eyes. May be harmful if swallowed, especially hook, line, and sinker. If allowed to dump in waterways, will cause H2 woes. http://www.BestPuns.Com

Did you think Dowd was defending Rice?  Surely she was not.  She was discussing what Rice might have been able to say at a commencement address -- if she weren't the person she is and hadn't retired from the fray.
Laws do not change human nature. They only create fear and the desire to find ways around them.

Libertarianism is anti-civilization; it seeks to destroy society by legitimizing greed and, with that, undo thousands of years of hard work to tame the reptilian traces that make human nature the awful and diagusting thing it is.

Civilization is not cheap and it's not a given. Humans are petty, greedy, unscrupulous animals willing to kill, maim, cheat and steal in their quest to accumulate material things. The only reason we're still here is because civilization has successfully tamed our nature (in some parts of the world) so we don't kill each other off.

Anyone who espouses libertarianism is an enemy of civilization and should be dealt with as such. Charles and David Koch fit the bill really well.
